channel.title: Bloomberg Economics
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Dire UK Data Ramp Up Pressure on BOE to Keep Cutting Rates
item.description: The Bank of England is facing pressure to push ahead with more interest-rate cuts after a week of woeful data showed the UK economy and labor market buckling under the weight of tax increases and US President Donald Trump’s trade war.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Philip Aldrick

item.title: Economists Predict Germany Will Return to Growth This Year
item.description: Germany’s economy will return to growth in 2025 after two years of contraction, according to analysts surveyed by Bloomberg who are a little more upbeat on the country’s near-term prospects than other forecasters.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Harumi Ichikura

item.title: SNB Is Set to Cut to Zero But Shirk From Negative Rate for Now
item.description: The Swiss National Bank will probably lower its interest rate to zero this week and stay there for some time, according to a Bloomberg survey of economists.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss, Harumi Ichikura

item.title: ECB Seen Cutting Once More as Officials Strike Cautious Tone
item.description: Economists still expect the European Central Bank to lower interest rates one more time this year, even after policymakers signaled they’re in no rush to ease further.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Harumi Ichikura

item.title: Israel-Iran Attacks Extend to Fourth Day With No Deal in Sight
item.description: Open hostilities between Israel and Iran entered a fourth day on Monday with no sign of easing, stoking fears of a wider war in the oil-rich region.
item.dc:creator: Arsalan Shahla, Galit Altstein

item.title: China’s Home Prices Fall Faster as Officials Pledge Support
item.description: China’s new-home prices fell the most in seven months in May, underscoring why senior government officials are renewing pledges to revive the property market.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Emma Dong

item.title: China Retail Sales Jump Most Since 2023 in Relief From Tariffs
item.description: China’s retail sales growth unexpectedly accelerated as the economy rode out the tariff rollercoaster in May, offering a confidence boost to Beijing as it stares down the threat of a prolonged trade war with the US.
item.dc:creator: Lucille Liu, Josh Xiao, Yujing Liu

item.title: China Cuts Steel Output as Beijing’s Curbs Start to Take Effect
item.description: China churned out a lot less steel in May compared to the previous year as mills responded to the government’s pledge to cut production.
item.dc:creator: Jason Rogers

item.title: Polls Show Support for Japan’s Ishiba Recovering Before Election
item.description: Public support for Japan’s prime minister is holding up after the government moved to address high rice prices, according to new opinion polls, a positive sign for Shigeru Ishiba as he heads into an election and tries to reach a trade agreement with the US.
item.dc:creator: Alastair Gale

item.title: BOJ to Weigh Slowdown in Bond Buying Cuts After Volatility Rises
item.description: The Bank of Japan is set to consider whether to taper its bond purchases at a slower pace while also leaving its benchmark interest rate unchanged, in a decision that will be closely scrutinized by the bond market.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

item.title: Japan’s Kato Says Talks With Markets Key for Bond Issuance
item.description: Japan’s finance minister said discussions with market participants are a key factor for ensuring government bonds are bought and sold stably ahead of a closely watched ministry meeting with investors.
item.dc:creator: Shery Ahn, Erica Yokoyama

item.title: Global Rate Limbo Reigns After 150 Days of Trump
item.description: Multiple central banks are set to keep interest rates frozen in the coming week while continuing to gauge the impact of trade disruptions instigated by US President Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

media:content.media:description: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Aug. 21, 2024. Chair Jerome Powell will usher in the next chapter in the Federal Reserve's inflation battle on Friday, when he's expected to set the table for an interest-rate cut while reassuring investors that policymakers can stave off a sharp economic slowdown.

item.title: Fed on Hold Leaves Wall Street Asking What It Will Take to Cut Interest Rates
item.description: With Federal Reserve officials signaling an extended hold on interest rates, investors and economists will look to Chair Jerome Powell this week for clues on what might eventually prompt the central bank to make a move, and when.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte, Ye Xie

media:content.media:description: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell and President Donald Trump

item.title: Peru’s Growth Misses Expectations as Fishing, Farming Contracts
item.description: Peru’s economic growth was weaker than expected in April, dragged down by slow growth in fishing and agriculture.
item.dc:creator: Marcelo Rochabrun

media:content.media:description: A worker sprays a tangerine orchard at a farm in Huacho, Peru, on Friday, Oct. 13, 2023. Damage to the agricultural sector by El Nino pushed the economy into a recession in the second quarter, with worse expected next year as El Nino conditions intensify.

item.title: Hungary Nominates Palotai as Central Bank Deputy Governor
item.description: Hungary nominated Daniel Palotai to become the fourth deputy governor of the central bank, a position created this month after Parliament passed an overhaul of the institution’s leadership.
item.dc:creator: Marton Kasnyik

media:content.media:description: Daniel Palotai, chief economist at the National Bank of Hungary, arrives for dinner during the Jackson Hole economic symposium, sponsored by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, in Moran, Wyoming, U.S., on Thursday, Aug. 23, 2018. Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell's debut address to the Wyoming gathering of central bankers this week will do little to shake financial markets if history is any guide.

item.title: RBA to Decide on Publishing Unattributed Votes at July Meeting
item.description: Australia’s central bank will decide at its July meeting whether to publish the unattributed votes of members of its new monetary policy board, according to a government spokesperson.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: A person enters the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) building in Sydney, Australia, on Monday, Feb. 6, 2023. Australia's central bank is all but certain to increase interest rates at its first meeting of the year, with some observers pointing to the risk of a resumption of outsized moves to counter a surprising surge in inflation.

item.title: Dollar Ructions Lay Groundwork for a ‘Global Euro Moment’
item.description: When the euro was born more than a quarter century ago, it arrived with much fanfare. Even the US Federal Reserve chair of the time, Alan Greenspan, was excited. “To the extent the euro becomes a far more formidable force in the world economy, it’s a benefit to everybody, especially the US,” he said in January 2000.
item.dc:creator: Craig Stirling

item.title: Charting the Global Economy: Israeli Airstrikes Boost Oil Prices
item.description: Crude oil prices surged and investors sought the safety of gold after Israel conducted airstrikes on Iranian atomic facilities involved in nuclear enrichment.
item.dc:creator: Vince Golle

item.title: ECB Within Reach of 2% Inflation Goal, Lagarde Tells Xinhua
item.description: The European Central Bank is approaching its goal for consumer-price growth, President Christine Lagarde said, warning of uncertainty emanating from US tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), at a rates decision news conference in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. The ECB lowered interest rates for the eighth time in a year after inflation dipped beneath 2% and the economy suffered repeated blows from US tariffs. Photographer: Alex Kraus/Bloomberg

item.title: Switzerland’s Likely Rate Cut to Zero Threatens to Test Banks
item.description: The Swiss National Bank’s next cut in borrowing costs may be about to cause a headache for banks, if officials end up experimenting with their first-ever interest rate of zero.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright
